[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: random_g1_points()] [Debug Assertion Safety] Line 133 debug_assert - in production, could incorrect vector lengths cause undefined behavior in cryptographic operations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: random_g1_points()] [Duplicate Points] Is there any check for duplicate G1 points in the vector, or could hash_to_curve collisions (however unlikely) create duplicates that break multi-signature security? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: random_g2_points()] [Extreme Performance DoS] Each G2 point takes 150 microseconds - n=1000 points takes 150 milliseconds, could this be weaponized to completely halt validator operations and cause loss of liveness? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: random_g2_points()] [Massive Memory Consumption] G2 points are 96 bytes each - n=10^6 requires 96MB, easily exploitable for memory exhaustion attacks if n is not bounded, is there validation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: random_g2_points()] [G2 Point Correlation] Similar to G1 but in G2 group - does sequential generation from same RNG compromise aggregate signature security? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: random_g2_points()] [Subgroup Check] Are all generated G2 points guaranteed to be in the correct prime-order subgroup, or could invalid points cause pairing check failures? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_gt_points()] [Batch Discrete Log Exposure] Generates n GT points where all discrete logs are known - if used in production, could this enable complete cryptographic break and fund theft? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_gt_points()] [Catastrophic Performance] 507 microseconds per point means n=1000 takes over 500 milliseconds - combined with discrete log exposure, this is doubly dangerous if misused, are there safeguards? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_gt_points()] [Warning Propagation] The WARNING on line 156 is in comments only - should this trigger compile-time errors or runtime panics if called outside test code? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_gt_points()] [Discrete Log Leakage Vector] Knowing n discrete logs could enable lattice attacks to derive additional secret information if these points interact with secure cryptographic operations, is there isolation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g1_points()] [Deterministic Generation] Lines 178-186 generate points deterministically via acc = acc.double() + shift - can attackers predict all future points given knowledge of the initial point and shift? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g1_points()] [Benchmarking Misuse] Line 173 says this is for benchmarking - if accidentally used in production consensus, could the predictable sequence enable signature forgery or double-spending? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g1_points()] [Point Doubling Weakness] The formula acc.double() + shift creates a predictable arithmetic sequence - could this pattern weaken cryptographic protocols that assume random points? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g1_points()] [Limited Entropy] Only two random points (point and shift) are used to generate n points - is this sufficient entropy, or does it reduce effective key space? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g1_points()] [Small Subgroup Attack] If shift happens to be a small-order point, could the generated sequence be confined to a small subgroup, enabling discrete log attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g1_points()] [Collision Risk] With only 2 random seeds for n points, collision probability increases - could duplicate points appear and break multi-signature schemes? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g1_points()] [No Insecure Prefix Warning] Unlike insecure_random_gt_point, this function name suggests insecurity but has minimal documentation warning - could developers misuse it thinking it's safe for non-critical keys? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g2_points()] [G2 Deterministic Sequence] Same deterministic generation as G1 but for G2 - if used for validator BLS public keys, could this enable complete compromise of consensus security? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g2_points()] [G2 Pattern Predictability] The acc.double() + shift pattern in G2 - could adversaries compute all future G2 points and precompute signature attacks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g2_points()] [Pairing Attack Vector] G2 is used in BLS signature verification pairings - could predictable G2 points enable pairing-based attacks on signature aggregation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g2_points()] [Combined G1/G2 Weakness] If both insecure_random_g1_points and insecure_random_g2_points are used together, does this create a catastrophic weakening of BLS signature security? (Critical)

(High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Constant: DST_RAND_CORE_HELL] [Separation Violation] If the same DST is used in other Aptos cryptographic contexts beyond randomness generation, could this break domain separation and enable signature forgery? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/blstrs/random.rs] [Constant: DST_RAND_CORE_HELL] [Length Restriction] BLS hash-to-curve standards recommend specific DST lengths - is 24 bytes compliant, or could non-standard length cause incompatibility or security issues? (Medium)
